org.prop4j.explain.solvers.impl.ltms

Class Ltms

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.prop4j.explain.solvers.impl.AbstractSatProblem
      • org.prop4j.explain.solvers.impl.ltms.Ltms
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    MusExtractor, MutableSatSolver, SatProblem, SatSolver

    public class Ltms
extends AbstractSatProblem
implements MusExtractor

    The class LTMS (logic truth maintenance system) records proofs for implications and constructs explanations. Uses BCP (boolean constraint propagation) for managing logical implications. BCP expects two parameters: initial truth values (premises) and a propositional formula in CNF (conjunctive normal form).

    Clauses are referenced by their index in the CNF.

    Note that this class does not fulfill the entire contract of each of its interfaces. This is because BCP is inherently incomplete, meaning it does not always find a result.

    Author:
    Sofia Ananieva, Timo Günther

      • isSatisfiable

        public boolean isSatisfiable()
        Description copied from interface: SatSolver

        Returns true iff the problem is satisfiable.

        More formally, let f denote the current (possibly empty) problem. Those are all the clauses that have been added to the problem. f is a conjunction of n ≥ 0 CNF clauses fi. Each clause fi in turn consists of a positive amount of possibly negated literals fij:

        f = f1 ∧ … ∧ fn
          = (f11 ∨ … ∨ f1m) ∧ … ∧ (fn1 ∨ … ∨ fnk)
        Then, f is satisfiable iff there is a variable assignment that satisfies f (i.e. makes it evaluate to true). Such an assignment is called model.
        Specified by:
        isSatisfiable in interface SatSolver
        Returns:
        whether the problem is satisfiable

      • getMinimalUnsatisfiableSubset

        public java.util.Set<Node> getMinimalUnsatisfiableSubset()
                                                  throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Description copied from interface: MusExtractor

        Returns any minimal unsatisfiable subset (MUS) of the problem. A MUS is any unsatisfiable subset of the formula which cannot be reduced any further without becoming satisfiable.

        A MUS can act as an explanation for why a formula is unsatisfiable. As such, the problem must be unsatisfiable for a MUS to be found.

        Specified by:
        getMinimalUnsatisfiableSubset in interface MusExtractor
        Returns:
        any minimal unsatisfiable subset; not null
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException

        Description copied from interface: MusExtractor
        Returns any minimal unsatisfiable subset (MUS) of the problem. Each clause is referenced by its index instead of object.

      • getAllMinimalUnsatisfiableSubsetIndexes

        public java.util.List<java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer>> getAllMinimalUnsatisfiableSubsetIndexes()
                                                                                         throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Returns all minimal unsatisfiable subsets of the problem referenced by index.

        Returns multiple explanations why the premises lead to a contradiction in the conjunctive normal form. This is done by propagating the truth values until a contradiction is found. Then, the proofs for the implications are recalled. This is repeated several times to find multiple explanations, some of which might be shorter than others.

        Specified by:
        getAllMinimalUnsatisfiableSubsetIndexes in interface MusExtractor
        Returns:
        all minimal unsatisfiable subsets of the problem referenced by index.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the formula in this solver is satisfiable
